issue.title: TSC/TSR: interface favourite UEA algorithms

labels.name: interfacing algorithms
labels.description: Interfacing existing algorithms/estimators for other packages

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Interface UEA algorithms from their dedicated module.

Obviousuly conditional on https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/9, the algorithms implemented, and https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/2, the predictor-estimator interface implemented.

body:
Also, should be in a separate module.
Generally, framework code should be separate from algorithm code. Both should be separate from interface code.

Should at least include these algorithms:
- Elastic Ensemble
- Shapelet Transform (+CAPE)
- Random Interval Spectral Ensemble

Prototype DTW 1NN classifier pushed to "nearest_neighbours" development branch with support for scikit-learn's GridSearchCV (DTW 1NN is a constituent of the Elastic Ensemble - other constituents are similar but with different distance measures)
Great! Is there a quick link to a reference experiment?

issue.title: TSC/TSR: the grand fantabulous time series classification and time series regression super mega hyper bake-off

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Bake-off in python toolbox with full set of methods and suite of post-hoc analyses.

Conditional on:
- data loading implemented https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/8
- baseline methods and transformer principles implemented https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/7
- UEA favourite methods implemented https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/10
- grid-tuning implemented https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/4

issue.title: GitFlow for UEA PhD mini-projects

labels.name: interfacing algorithms
labels.description: Interfacing existing algorithms/estimators for other packages

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This is arising from #9 and #10, and @TonyBagnall 's suggestion of sub-projects.

I propose to have one branch per algorithm in development, then @jasonlines @TonyBagnall to review & approve pull requests into dev.

Collaborators to be added here - I think with the golden Turing subscription to Github we have fine-grained control over credentials etc.

body:
Sitrep: our approach to this is agile: we are going for stripped down sklearn versions in numpy first to test correctness and to serve as a benchmark on timing for the pipeline versions. We aim to run all on the default train/test splits, ideally before the march meeting. tl;dr we will have a set of results to generate any required graphs for the poster, completeness of them is uncertain. There are five hive-cote components
1. TSF: we have two alternative implementations, mine and Marcus's. Both are not significantly different in accuracy from the java version (and each other) on a decent subset of the data, but the pipeline one is significantly slower than the numpy one. The reason needs determining, and I need to compare latest timings from the Marcus version tomorrow. 
2. RISE:  numpy based implemented  and running, will have correctness and timing by tuesday. Simple port to pipeline version. 
3. BOSS: we have a first implementation, not optimised for speed, we need to work on it a bit. Running, will have about 70% complete by tuesday
4. EE: Jasons base version is running (he can confirm) but pig slow. cython implementation in the works
5. ST:  Jasons base version is running (he can confirm), David is working on refinements.   

once the bakeoff recreation is complete, we need to decide on priorities. Issues include
1. Resolve slowness of pipeline version and adapt implementations into this format if appropriate
2. Handle missing values for each module, either with a bespoke algorithm adjustments internally to the classifier or through standard transforms as a contained object
3. Handle unequal length series, as above
4. Implement naive multivariate version (dimensions independent)
we can then complete the bakeoff on all the new univariate data and the multivariate also. I would hope to get all this done for HIVE-COTE by end of the project. If renewed, we can obviously move it all forward further. There are several recently published algorithms we can port in with the help of the authors, one I'm currently reviewing for KDD!

Yep to confirm, I've been taking a fair bit of pain with our HPC over Friday and Monday but I have experiments running over the initial 85 datasets for the shapelet transform (versions contracted to 10 minutes, 1 hours, 4 hours, 1 day) with a random forest as the model. For EE, the slow version is chugging away on the cluster (separate jobs for constituents, will write code to post-process results for the fill EE). Likely to be _very_ slow however, so cython investigation ongoing

So, how are you running them?
Is this manual code for benchmarking? Or is there a module that we haven't spotted?

so update on implementations/functionality of specific algorithms
in sktime.classifiers: boss, rise, tsf, ee, proximity_forest
in sktime.contrib (to be ported):  bop, rotation forest another elastic_ensemble?.
in forks, awaiting assimilation: 9 kernel methods  
in https://github.com/uea-machine-learning/sktime-dl: 8 deep learning classifiers.

have I missed any? Could someone list the configurable classifiers? Straight pipeline, ensemble pipeline and dimension ensemble iirc?
so I can finally say this is done. I have run locally versions of TSF, RISE, BOSS, EE, ST and PF in sktime. Discussion of benchmarking can move to the bakeoff issue
